text: <@U02LGA1DB9N> Ohh okay! It may not be too bad then - most of the "branding packages" I've worked on have been in the 3-4k range - but that price does include more than just tone/voice guide. So I guess it all depends on how much you are adding into that deliverable.

elements.text: Ohh okay! It may not be too bad then - most of the "branding packages" I've worked on have been in the 3-4k range - but that price does include more than just tone/voice guide. So I guess it all depends on how much you are adding into that deliverable.

text: Things I'm good at: writing. Things I'm bad at: pricing. Now that we have cleared THAT up, how much would you charge for sales copy for a landing page? (It's B2C) (I typically charge 200 for Blogs/Articles, but sales copy is a different beast, and it's been awhile since I've had to price it out. I last did it within an agency umbrella so I was just in charge of writing.)

text: Why don’t you try something along the lines of “From $300, depending on the subject, deadline and amount of research and interviews needed. Includes 2 rounds of tweaking”

elements.text: Why don’t you try something along the lines of “From $300, depending on the subject, deadline and amount of research and interviews needed. Includes 2 rounds of tweaking”

text: :slightly_smiling_face: I know the feeling about pricing. It is always a tough call.  If the scope of work is clear, you should be able to guestimate the amount of hours it will take you and charge a fee based on that. I would say something like, "my copywriting fee is $x/hr and this will take me x hours".  So if there are curveballs you can manage expenses by letting them know it will require more hours.  For example with web copy, there are often many  client edits / comments depending on how many stakeholders are approving it. I often add a caveat that the proposal includes 2 rounds of edits. This way it is easy to charge more when they need more rounds.  If you are trying to figure out an exact $ amount, it really depends on the client/industry. How long does a $200 blog take you to do? That is a good starting point to find an hourly that you are comfortable with, but def increase it a bit for copywriting as it is a specialized skillset. Hope that helps.

This way it is easy to charge more when they need more rounds.  If you are trying to figure out an exact $ amount, it really depends on the client/industry. How long does a $200 blog take you to do? That is a good starting point to find an hourly that you are comfortable with, but def increase it a bit for copywriting as it is a specialized skillset. Hope that helps.

text:
We have over 150 freelance writers right now (worldwide), so happy to offer insights into growing your writer base.

The best places I’ve found for getting writers are:

• <https://contentwritingjobs.com/>
• <https://weworkremotely.com/>
• <https://dynamitejobs.com/>
And we use <http://Pilot.co|Pilot.co> to handle our payroll. It’s very reasonably priced ($30/contractor/mo) and you pay no fees for any country worldwide. Highly recommend it.

text: Greetings, Channel Freelance! I’m looking for a developer with HubSpot API (and other REST APIs) experience. I am trying to pull some third-party data to supplement my first-party data and the source is another platform that also has REST APIs. I have thus far unsuccessfully attempted various connectors (e.g., Zapier). If this sounds like you or someone you know, drop me a DM. :cattyping:

Buddy’s startup is seeking a freelance content marketer.
Are you the right person? Reach out to
him
at
leonard@tell.ie
(not me! I’m just the messenger!)
Over to Leonard…
We (
Tellie

) are looking for a content marketing contractor (min 6 months) or a full-time hire (or contract-to-hire). We are looking for someone with experience in the no-code website building/creator space (doesn’t have to be an exact match).

You will manage all of our content marketing including: 

- crafting content for various channels (social, blog, etc)
- business relations (getting our content on third parties)
- SEO

The primary goal is organic custom acquisition -- we want an engine that feeds our top of the funnel. That will change as we get more users, but for now, it’s the primary goal.
Budget Info

• Full-time hire: $110k-$150k depending on seniority. Not sure what the contracting rates would be, but we will try our best to be competitive.

• Our marketing budget is $10k per month and the content marketing budget would come from that
Tellie

allows every creator to build a home for your creativity in minutes. It gives the power of a website with the ease of a link-in-bio tool. With Tellie’s novel design, your work stands out on mobile and desktop. Tell stories across formats and platforms, pairing video, audio, text, images, GIFs, shops, links, and more—creating connections never before possible. Drive valuable stats like streams and views while keeping fans in an experience you own. At Tellie, we don’t prioritize meaningless clicks. We help you build direct relationships with your fans. Your site. Your story. With
Tellie
Reach out to:
leonard@tell.ie

text:
*Looking for advice: long-term freelance client not paying due to COVID*

For 3 years, I had been working with a small Aussie marketing agency specializing in sales funnels and Facebook ads.

When COVID happened, they started missing payments. I wasn't worried at first because I have a long-term relationship with them and never had any issues with them before, so I let it slide for a couple of months.

After a while, I realized the debt kept getting bigger and bigger, so I stopped working with them.

Currently, they owe me ~3 months worth of wages :smiling_face_with_tear: It's been 5 months, but so far I only got a very small portion of the money they owe me. They are in contact (which is good) but they keep saying they can't pay because the lockdowns in Australia caused them to lose clients and they simply don't have the money.

I suggested a payment plan but their response is "we'll pay you once we can but we don't know when that will be".

Any advice on what else I can do in this situation is appreciated!

elements.text: Looking for advice: long-term freelance client not paying due to COVID

For 3 years, I had been working with a small Aussie marketing agency specializing in sales funnels and Facebook ads.

When COVID happened, they started missing payments. I wasn't worried at first because I have a long-term relationship with them and never had any issues with them before, so I let it slide for a couple of months.

After a while, I realized the debt kept getting bigger and bigger, so I stopped working with them.

Currently, they owe me ~3 months worth of wages

It's been 5 months, but so far I only got a very small portion of the money they owe me. They are in contact (which is good) but they keep saying they can't pay because the lockdowns in Australia caused them to lose clients and they simply don't have the money.

I suggested a payment plan but their response is "we'll pay you once we can but we don't know when that will be".

Any advice on what else I can do in this situation is appreciated!
